body:
![num.cr](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/crystal-data/bottle/rename/static/numcr_logo.png)

[![Join the chat at https://gitter.im/crystal-data/bottle](https://badges.gitter.im/crystal-data/bottle.svg)](https://gitter.im/crystal-data/bottle?utm_source=badge&utm_medium=badge&utm_campaign=pr-badge&utm_content=badge)
[![Build Status](https://travis-ci.com/crystal-data/num.cr.svg?branch=master)](https://travis-ci.com/crystal-data/num.cr)

Num.cr is the core shard needed for scientific computing with Crystal

- **Website:** https://crystal-data.github.io/num.cr
- **API Documentation:** https://crystal-data.github.io/num.cr/
- **Source code:** https://github.com/crystal-data/num.cr
- **Bug reports:** https://github.com/crystal-data/num.cr/issues

It provides:

- An n-dimensional `Tensor` data structure
- sophisticated reduction and accumulation routines
- data structures that can easily be passed to C libraries
- powerful linear algebra routines backed by LAPACK and BLAS

## Prerequisites

Num.cr relies on various BLAS and LAPACK implementations to provide performant linear
algebra routines.  The defaults are OpenBLAS and Lapacke.  On Darwin, the Accelerate
framework is used by default.  Num.cr also allows for computing run on a GPU, backed
by OpenCL, with BLAS operations backed by ClBlast.  Please review the relevant installation
instructions for these libraries if you would like to take advantage of their features.

## Usage

Num.cr provides data structures that facilitate element-wise operations,
accumulations, and reductions.  While some operations are backed by BLAS
and LaPACK, many vectorized operations use iteration written in Crystal.
The primary goal of this library was to provide a NumPy like interface in
Crystal, and performance will be revisited constantly as the library is
improved.

Contributing
------------
Num.cr requires help in many different ways to continue to grow as a shard.
Contributions such as high level documentation and code quality checks are needed just
as much as API enhancements.  If you are considering larger scale contributions
that extend beyond minor enhancements and bug fixes, contact Crystal Data
in order to be added to the organization to gain access to review and merge
permissions.

## Installation

Add this to your applications `shard.yml`

```
dependencies:
  num:
    github: crystal-data/num.cr
```

## Getting started with Num.cr

The core data structure of Num.cr is the `Tensor`, a flexible N-dimensional data structure.
There are many ways to initialize a `Tensor`, or a `ClTensor` if you need GPU accelerated
operations.

```crystal
[1, 2, 3].to_tensor
Tensor.from_array [1, 2, 3]
Tensor(UInt8).zeros([3, 3, 2])
Tensor.random(0.0...1.0, [2, 2, 2])

ClTensor(Float32).zeros_like(some_tensor)
ClTensor(Float64).full([3, 4, 5], 3.8)
```

Tensors support numerous mathematical operations and manipulation routines, including
operations requiring broadcasting to other shapes.

```crystal
a = [1, 2, 3, 4].to_tensor
b = [[3, 4, 5, 6], [5, 6, 7, 8]].to_tensor

# Convert a Tensor to a GPU backed Tensor
acl = a.astype(Float64).opencl

puts Num.add(a, b)

# a is broadcast to b's shape
# [[ 4,  6,  8, 10],
#  [ 6,  8, 10, 12]]

puts a.reshape(2, 2)

# [[1, 2],
#  [3, 4]]

puts b.transpose

# [[3, 5],
#  [4, 6],
#  [5, 7],
#  [6, 8]]

puts Num.cos(acl).cpu

# [0.540302 , -0.416147, -0.989992, -0.653644]
```

Both CPU backed Tensors and GPU backed Tensors support linear algebra routines
backed by optimized BLAS libraries.

```crystal
a = [[1, 2], [3, 4]].to_tensor.astype(Float32)
b = [[3, 4], [5, 6]].to_tensor.astype(Float32)

acl = a.opencl
bcl = b.opencl

puts a.inv

# [[-2  , 1   ],
#  [1.5 , -0.5]]

puts acl.matmul(bcl).cpu

# [[13, 16],
#  [29, 36]]
```

Review the documentation for full implementation details, and if something is missing,
open an issue to add it!

def.name: extend_crystal_arithmetic
from_array
def.body:
newshape = calculate_shape(array)
newstrides = NumInternal.shape_to_strides(newshape)
ptr = array.flatten.to_unsafe
new(ptr, newshape, newstrides)

def.name: from_json
def.body:
ret = new(shape)
ret_iter = NumInternal::UnsafeContigFlatIter.new(ret)
parser = JSON::PullParser.new(string_or_io)
parser.read_array do
  ret_iter.next.value = T.new(parser)
end
ret

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc:
Initialization method for a generic buffer, shape and strides.
This method updates flags on the passed array, if the array
is read only, its flags need to be updated later
constructors.summary: Initialization method for a generic buffer, shape and strides.
constructors.args_string: (buffer : Pointer(T), shape, strides, flags = Num::ArrayFlags::All)

def.name: new
def.body:
_ = AnyArray(T).allocate
_.initialize(buffer, shape, strides, flags)
if _.responds_to?(:finalize)
  ::GC.add_finalizer(_)
end
_

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc:
Initializes an ndarray from a provided shape and memory layout.
Flags will be auto-computed
constructors.summary: Initializes an ndarray from a provided shape and memory layout.
constructors.args_string: (shape : Array(Int32), order : Num::OrderType = Num::RowMajor)

constructors.name: new
constructors.args_string: (shape : Array(Int32), value : T, order : Num::OrderType = Num::RowMajor)

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc:
Crates a scalar tensor, that acts like a scalar while still being
a Tensor.  This was primarily added so that indexing operations
could return single elements without having a union return type.
constructors.summary: Crates a scalar tensor, that acts like a scalar while still being a Tensor.

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc:
Yields an array from a provided shape and a block.  The block only
provides the absolute index, not an index dependent on the shape,
so if a user wants to handle an arbitrary shape inside the block
they need to do that themselves.
constructors.summary: Yields an array from a provided shape and a block.
constructors.args_string: (shape : Array(Int32), order : Num::OrderType = Num::RowMajor, &block : Int32 -> T)

def.name: new
def.body:
size = shape.product
ptr = Pointer(T).malloc(size) do |i|
  yield i
end
strides = NumInternal.shape_to_strides(shape, order)
new(ptr, shape, strides)

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc:
Yields an array from a provided number of rows and columns.
This can quickly create matrices, useful for several `Tensor` creattion
methods such as the underlying implementation of `eye`, and `diag`.

This method does provide *i* and *j* variables for the passed block,
so no offset calculations need to be done by the user.
constructors.summary: Yields an array from a provided number of rows and columns.
constructors.args_string: (nrows : Int32, ncols : Int32, &block : Int32, Int32 -> T)

def.name: new
def.body:
data = Pointer(T).malloc(nrows * ncols) do |idx|
  i = idx // ncols
  j = idx % ncols
  yield i, j
end
if (nrows == 0) || (ncols == 0)
  raise(NumInternal::ShapeError.new("Cannot initialize an empty matrix"))
end
strides = NumInternal.shape_to_strides([nrows, ncols], Num::RowMajor)
new(data, [nrows, ncols], strides)

instance_methods.doc:
Returns a view of an ndarray from a list of indexers.
Valid indexers are integers, such as `1` or `2`, ranges, such
as `...` or `1...`, and tuples of a range, and an integer representing
the step of the index operation, such as `{..., -1}`
instance_methods.summary: Returns a view of an ndarray from a list of indexers.

instance_methods.doc:
Writes to a view of an ndarray given a list of indexers and a value to
map across the array.  This is equivalent to the variadic method in
actual functionality
instance_methods.summary: Writes to a view of an ndarray given a list of indexers and a value to map across the array.

instance_methods.doc:
Writes to a view of an ndarray given a variadic tuple of indexers and a value to
map across the array.  The value to map will always be the last value
provided as args, so with some macro magic we can defer to the correct
method
instance_methods.summary: Writes to a view of an ndarray given a variadic tuple of indexers and a value to map across the array.

def.name: astype
def.body:
ret = (self.basetype(U)).new(@shape)
{% if U == Bool %}
      ret.map2!(self) do |_, j|
        j != 0
      end
    {% else %}
      ret.map2!(self) do |_, j|
        U.new(j)
      end
    {% end %}
ret

instance_methods.name: diag_view
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a view of the diagonal of an array.  Only valid if
the array has two dimensions.  Offsets are not supported.
instance_methods.summary: Returns a view of the diagonal of an array.

def.name: diag_view
def.body:
if ndims == 2
else
  raise(NumInternal::ShapeError.new("Array must be two-dimensional"))
end
nel = @shape.min
newshape = [nel]
newstrides = [@strides.sum]
newflags = @flags.dup
newflags = newflags & (~Num::ArrayFlags::OwnData)
ret = self.class.new(to_unsafe, newshape, newstrides, newflags)
ret.update_flags(Num::ArrayFlags::Fortran | Num::ArrayFlags::Contiguous)
ret

instance_methods.name: dup
instance_methods.doc:
Duplicates a BaseArray, respecting the passed order of memory
provided.  Useful for throwing ndarrays down to LAPACK
since they must be in Fortran style order
instance_methods.summary: Duplicates a BaseArray, respecting the passed order of memory provided.

def.name: dup
def.body:
contig = uninitialized Num::ArrayFlags
case order
when Num::RowMajor
  contig = Num::ArrayFlags::Contiguous
when Num::ColMajor
  contig = Num::ArrayFlags::Fortran
when nil
  contig = @flags & (Num::ArrayFlags::Contiguous | Num::ArrayFlags::Fortran)
else
  raise(NumInternal::ValueError.new("Invalid argument for order.  Valid options are RowMajor, or ColMajor"))
end
contig_char = contig.fortran? ? Num::ColMajor : Num::RowMajor
ret = self.class.new(@shape, contig_char)
if ((contig & @flags) != Num::ArrayFlags::None)
  self.to_unsafe.copy_to(ret.to_unsafe, @size)
else
  ret.map2!(self) do |_, j|
    j
  end
end
ret.update_flags
ret

instance_methods.name: dup_view
instance_methods.doc:
Shallow copies the array.  Shape and strides are copied, but
the underlying data is not.  The returned array does
not own its own data, and its base reflects that.
instance_methods.summary: Shallow copies the array.

def.name: dup_view
def.body:
newshape = @shape.dup
newstrides = @strides.dup
newflags = @flags.dup
newflags = newflags & (~Num::ArrayFlags::OwnData)
self.class.new(to_unsafe, newshape, newstrides, newflags)

instance_methods.name: iter
instance_methods.doc:
Returns an iterator over the flattened elements of an array.
This iterator will always iterate in C-contiguous order, regardless
of the strides of the array.  It will iterate much faster over
arrays that are c-contiguous
instance_methods.summary: Returns an iterator over the flattened elements of an array.

def.name: iter
def.body:
if flags.contiguous?
  NumInternal::ContigFlatIter.new(self)
else
  NumInternal::NDFlatIter.new(self)
end

def.name: iter2
def.body:
if flags.contiguous? && other.flags.contiguous?
  NumInternal::ContigFlatIter2.new(self, other)
else
  NumInternal::NDFlatIter2.new(self, other)
end

instance_methods.name: iter3
instance_methods.args_string: (o1 : AnyArray(U), o2 : AnyArray(V)) forall U, V

def.name: iter3
def.body:
if (flags.contiguous? && o1.flags.contiguous?) && o2.flags.contiguous?
  NumInternal::ContigFlatIter3.new(self, o1, o2)
else
  NumInternal::NDFlatIter3.new(self, o1, o2)
end

def.name: iter_flat_indexed
def.body:
i = 0
if flags.contiguous?
  (NumInternal::ContigFlatIter.new(self)).each do |el|
    yield el, i
    i = i + 1
  end
else
  (NumInternal::NDFlatIter.new(self)).each do |el|
    yield el, i
    i = i + 1
  end
end

instance_methods.name: map
instance_methods.doc:
Maps an ndarray and returns a copy, storing the result of the yielded block.
This can result in a different return type, since the operation allocates
a new array before returning, so no casting will occur back to the original
dtype
instance_methods.summary: Maps an ndarray and returns a copy, storing the result of the yielded block.

def.name: map
def.body:
ret = (basetype(U)).new(shape)
(ret.iter2(self)).each do |i, j|
  i.value = yield j.value
end
ret

instance_methods.name: map!
instance_methods.doc:
Maps an ndarray in place, storing the result of the yielded block.
Since this is an in-place operation, the result is cast to the type
of the input, and information may be lost if the operation otherwise
would have required a cast.
instance_methods.summary: Maps an ndarray in place, storing the result of the yielded block.

def.name: map!
def.body:
iter.each do |i|
  i.value = T.new(yield i.value)
end

instance_methods.name: map2
instance_methods.doc:
Maps a function across two ndarrays.  This returns a copy, so no casting
will occur, and the arrays will be broadcast against each other
before returning.
instance_methods.summary: Maps a function across two ndarrays.
instance_methods.args_string: (other : AnyArray(U), &block : T, U -> V) forall U, V

def.name: map2
def.body:
a, b = NumInternal.broadcast2(self, other)
ret = (basetype(V)).new(a.shape)
(ret.iter3(a, b)).each do |i, j, k|
  i.value = yield j.value, k.value
end
ret

instance_methods.name: map2!
instance_methods.doc:
Maps a function across two ndarrays.  This is an inplace operation, so the
shape of the other array must be broadcastable to the shape of the input
array.
instance_methods.summary: Maps a function across two ndarrays.

def.name: map2!

instance_methods.name: map3
instance_methods.doc:
Maps a function across three ndarrays.  The arrays will be broadcast
against each other and a copy will be made.  The result type is based
on the resulting type of the block, and no casting will  occur since
a new array is allocated.
instance_methods.summary: Maps a function across three ndarrays.
instance_methods.args_string: (o1 : AnyArray(U), o2 : AnyArray(V), &block : T, U, V -> W) forall U, V, W

def.name: map3
def.body:
a, b, c = NumInternal.broadcast(self, o1, o2)
ret = (basetype(W)).new(a.shape)
(NumInternal::NDFlatIter4.new(ret, a, b, c)).each do |i, j, k, l|
  i.value = yield j.value, k.value, l.value
end
ret

instance_methods.name: map3!
instance_methods.doc:
Maps a function across three ndarrays in place.  The shapes of the
last two arrays must be broadcastable to the original two arrays,
so that the operation can be handled in place.  Casting will
occur if the result is not of type T
instance_methods.summary: Maps a function across three ndarrays in place.

def.name: map3!
def.body:
o1 = NumInternal.bcast_if(o1, shape)
o2 = NumInternal.bcast_if(o2, shape)
(NumInternal::NDFlatIter3.new(self, o1, o2)).each do |i, j, k|
  i.value = T.new(yield i.value, j.value, k.value)
end

instance_methods.name: ravel
instance_methods.doc:
Return a contiguous flattened array.
A 1-D array, containing the elements of the input, is returned.
A copy is made only if needed.
instance_methods.summary: Return a contiguous flattened array.

instance_methods.name: reduce_fast
instance_methods.doc: Reduces a tensor along an axis
instance_methods.summary: Reduces a tensor along an axis

def.name: reduce_fast
def.body:
if axis < 0
  axis = ndims + axis
end
if axis < ndims
else
  raise("Axis out of range for this array")
end
newshape = shape.dup
newstrides = strides.dup
ptr = to_unsafe
if !keepdims
  newshape.delete_at(axis)
  newstrides.delete_at(axis)
else
  newshape[axis] = 1
  newstrides[axis] = 0
end
ret = (self.class.new(to_unsafe, newshape, newstrides, flags)).dup
1.step(to: shape[axis] - 1) do |_|
  ptr = ptr + strides[axis]
  tmp = self.class.new(ptr, newshape, newstrides, flags)
  ret.map2!(tmp) do |x, y|
    yield x, y
  end
end
ret

instance_methods.name: reshape
instance_methods.doc: Gives a new shape to an array without changing its data.
instance_methods.summary: Gives a new shape to an array without changing its data.

def.name: reshape
def.body:
if newshape == shape
  return self
end
newsize = 1
cur_size = size
autosize = -1
newshape.each_with_index do |val, i|
  if val < 0
    if autosize >= 0
      raise(NumInternal::ValueError.new("Only shape dimension can be automatic"))
    end
    autosize = i
  else
    newsize = newsize * val
  end
end
if autosize >= 0
  newshape = newshape.dup
  newshape[autosize] = cur_size // newsize
  newsize = newsize * newshape[autosize]
end
if newsize != cur_size
  raise(NumInternal::ShapeError.new("Shapes #{shape} cannot be reshaped to #{newshape}"))
end
if flags & Num::ArrayFlags::Contiguous
  newstrides = NumInternal.shape_to_strides(newshape, Num::RowMajor)
else
  newstrides = NumInternal.shape_to_strides(newshape, Num::ColMajor)
end
if flags.fortran? || flags.contiguous?
  newflags = flags.dup
  newflags = newflags & (~Num::ArrayFlags::OwnData)
  ret = self.class.new(to_unsafe, newshape, newstrides, newflags)
  ret.update_flags(Num::ArrayFlags::Fortran | Num::ArrayFlags::Contiguous)
  ret
else
  tmp = dup
  ret = self.class.new(tmp.to_unsafe, newshape, newstrides, tmp.flags.dup)
  ret.update_flags(Num::ArrayFlags::Fortran | Num::ArrayFlags::Contiguous)
  ret
end

def.body:
order = (0...arr.ndims).to_a
order[axis1] = axis2
order[axis2] = axis1
transpose(arr, order)

instance_methods.name: transpose
instance_methods.doc:
Permute the dimensions of a `Tensor`.  If no order is provided,
the dimensions will be reversed, a "true transpose".  Otherwise,
the dimensions will be permutated in the order provided.
instance_methods.summary: Permute the dimensions of a Tensor.

def.name: transpose
def.body:
newshape = shape.dup
newstrides = strides.dup
if order.size == 0
  order = (0...ndims).to_a.reverse
end
n = order.size
if n != ndims
  raise(NumInternal::AxisError.new("Axes don't match array"))
end
permutation = [0] * 32
reverse_permutation = [0] * 32
n.times do |i|
  reverse_permutation[i] = -1
end
n.times do |i|
  axis = order[i]
  if axis < 0
    axis = ndims + axis
  end
  if axis < 0 || axis >= ndims
    raise(NumInternal::AxisError.new("Invalid axis for this array"))
  end
  if reverse_permutation[axis] != -1
    raise(NumInternal::AxisError.new("Repeated axis in transpose"))
  end
  reverse_permutation[axis] = i
  permutation[i] = axis
end
n.times do |i|
  newshape[i] = shape[permutation[i]]
  newstrides[i] = strides[permutation[i]]
end
ret = self.class.new(to_unsafe, newshape, newstrides, flags.dup)
ret.update_flags(Num::ArrayFlags::Contiguous | Num::ArrayFlags::Fortran)
ret

instance_methods.name: write?
instance_methods.doc:
Checks the write flag on an array, raising a WriteError
if the array is read-only, such as an array returned
from a method like as_strided
instance_methods.summary: Checks the write flag on an array, raising a WriteError if the array is read-only, such as an array returned from a method like as_strided

def.name: write?
def.body:
if !flags.write?
  raise(NumInternal::WriteError.new("Array is read only"))
end

types.name: Array
types.doc:
An `Array` is an ordered, integer-indexed collection of objects of type T.

Array indexing starts at 0. A negative index is assumed to be
relative to the end of the array: -1 indicates the last element,
-2 is the next to last element, and so on.

An `Array` can be created using the usual `new` method (several are provided), or with an array literal:

```
Array(Int32).new  # => []
[1, 2, 3]         # Array(Int32)
[1, "hello", 'x'] # Array(Int32 | String | Char)
```

An `Array` can have mixed types, meaning T will be a union of types, but these are determined
when the array is created, either by specifying T or by using an array literal. In the latter
case, T will be set to the union of the array literal elements' types.

When creating an empty array you must always specify T:

```
[] of Int32 # same as Array(Int32)
[]          # syntax error
```

An `Array` is implemented using an internal buffer of some capacity
and is reallocated when elements are pushed to it when more capacity
is needed. This is normally known as a [dynamic array](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_array).

You can use a special array literal syntax with other types too, as long as they define an argless
`new` method and a `<<` method. `Set` is one such type:

```
set = Set{1, 2, 3} # => Set{1, 2, 3}
set.class          # => Set(Int32)
```

The above is the same as this:

```
set = Set(typeof(1, 2, 3)).new
set << 1
set << 2
set << 3
```
types.summary: An Array is an ordered, integer-indexed collection of objects of type T.

def.name: check_type
cpu
def.body:

types.name: Complex
types.doc:
A complex number is a number represented in the form a + bi. In this form,
a and b are real numbers, and i is an imaginary number such as i = -1.
The a is the real part of the number, and the b is the imaginary part of
the number.

```
require "complex"

Complex.new(1, 0)   # => 1.0 + 0.0i
Complex.new(5, -12) # => 5.0 - 12.0i

1.to_c # => 1.0 + 0.0i
1.i    # => 0.0 + 1.0i
```
types.summary: A complex number is a number represented in the form a + bi.

instance_methods.name: allclose
instance_methods.doc:
Asserts that two equally shaped `Tensor`s are equal within a provided
tolerance.  Useful for floating point comparison where direct equality might
not work

```
t = Tensor.new([2, 2, 3]) { |i| i * 1.0 }
tf = t + 0.00000000001
allclose(t, tf) # => true
```
instance_methods.summary: Asserts that two equally shaped Tensors are equal within a provided tolerance.
instance_methods.args_string: (a : AnyArray(U), b : AnyArray(U), rtol = 1e-5, atol = 1e-8) forall U

def.name: allclose
def.body:
if a.shape != b.shape
  raise(NumInternal::ShapeError.new("Shape of arguments must match"))
end
iter_a = a.iter
iter_b = b.iter
if (rtol > 0)
  (iter_a.zip(iter_b)).each do |i, j|
    c = !((i.value - j.value).abs > (atol + (rtol * j.value.abs)))
    if c
    else
      return false
    end
  end
else
  (iter_a.zip(iter_b)).each do |i, j|
    c = (i.value - j.value).abs > atol
    if c
    else
      return false
    end
  end
end
true

def.name: assert_compatible_shape
def.body:
toraise = false
if a.size == 0
  if b != 0
    toraise = true
  end
else
  sz = a.reduce do |i, j|
    i * j
  end
  if b == sz
  else
    toraise = true
  end
end
if toraise
  raise(NumInternal::ShapeError.new("An array of size #{b} cannot go\n        into a Tensor of shape #{a}"))
end

instance_methods.name: astensor
instance_methods.doc:
Converts input data, in any form that can be converted to a tensor,
into a tensor.

This includes arrays, nested arrays, scalars, and tensors.
Data will not be copied unless necessary.  Base classes will not
be maintained, all inputs will be coerced to Tensors or raise.

def.name: atleast_1d
def.body:
if inp.ndims == 0
  Tensor.new([1]) do |_|
    inp.value
  end
else
  inp
end

def.name: atleast_2d
def.body:
if inp.ndims > 1
  inp
else
  if inp.ndims == 0
    Tensor.new([1, 1]) do |_|
      inp.value
    end
  else
    inp.reshape([1, inp.size])
  end
end

def.name: atleast_3d
def.body:
if inp.ndims > 2
  inp
else
  dim = 3 - inp.ndims
  newshape = ([1] * dim) + inp.shape
  inp.reshape(newshape)
end

def.name: column_stack
def.body:
alist = alist.map do |e|
  Num.atleast_1d(e)
end
first = alist[0]
shape = first.shape
NumInternal.assert_shape(shape, alist)
case first.ndims
when 1
  alist = alist.map do |a|
    a.reshape([a.size, 1])
  end
  concatenate(alist, 1)
when 2
  concatenate(alist, 1)
else
  raise(NumInternal::ShapeError.new("dstack was given arrays with more than two dimensions"))
end

instance_methods.name: concatenate
instance_methods.doc:
Join a sequence of arrays along an existing axis.
The arrays must have the same shape, except in the dimension corresponding
to axis (the first, by default).
instance_methods.summary: Join a sequence of arrays along an existing axis.

def.name: concatenate
def.body:
NumInternal.raise_zerod(alist)
newshape = alist[0].shape.dup
axis = NumInternal.clip_axis(axis, newshape.size)
newshape[axis] = 0
shape = NumInternal.assert_shape_off_axis(alist, axis, newshape)
ret = alist[0].class.new(newshape)
lo = [0] * newshape.size
hi = shape.dup
hi[axis] = 0
alist.each do |a|
  if a.shape[axis] != 0
    __temp_47 = axis
    hi[__temp_47] = hi[__temp_47] + a.shape[axis]
    ranges = (lo.zip(hi)).map do |i, j|
      i...j
    end
    ret[ranges] = a
    lo[axis] = hi[axis]
  end
end
ret

instance_methods.name: concatenate
instance_methods.doc: Concatenates an array of one dimensional tensors.
instance_methods.summary: Concatenates an array of one dimensional tensors.

def.name: concatenate
def.body:
totalsize = alist.reduce(0) do |i, j|
  i + j.size
end
ret = alist[0].class.new([totalsize])
offset = 0
alist.each do |a|
  ret[offset...(offset + a.size)] = a
  offset = offset + a.size
end
ret

def.name: dstack
def.body:
alist = alist.map do |e|
  Num.atleast_1d(e)
end
first = alist[0]
shape = first.shape
NumInternal.assert_shape(shape, alist)
case first.ndims
when 1
  alist = alist.map do |a|
    a.reshape([1, a.size, 1])
  end
  concatenate(alist, 2)
when 2
  alist = alist.map do |a|
    a.reshape(a.shape + [1])
  end
  concatenate(alist, 2)
else
  raise(NumInternal::ShapeError.new("dstack was given arrays with more than two dimensions"))
end

instance_methods.name: hstack
instance_methods.doc: Concatenates a list of `Tensor`s along axis 1
instance_methods.summary: Concatenates a list of Tensors along axis 1

def.name: hstack
def.body:
alist = alist.map do |e|
  Num.atleast_1d(e)
end
NumInternal.less_than_3d(alist)
if alist.all? do |t|
  t.ndims == 1
end
  concatenate(alist)
else
  concatenate(alist, 1)
end

instance_methods.name: stack
instance_methods.args_string: (alist : Array(AnyArray(U)), axis : Int32 = 0) forall U

def.name: stack
def.body:
first = alist[0]
shape = first.shape
assert_shape(shape, alist)
if alist.all? do |e|
  e.ndims == 0
end
  return concatenate(alist)
end
assert_all_1d(alist)
expanded_arrays = alist.map do |e|
  e.bc(axis)
end
concatenate(expanded_arrays, axis)

def.name: std
def.body: sqrt(divide(sum(power(subtract(a, mean(a, axis, keepdims: true)), 2), axis, keepdims), a.shape[axis]))

constants.name: Contiguous
constants.doc:
Contiguous really means C-style contiguious.  The
contiguous part means that there are no 'skipped
elements'.  That is, that a flat_iter over the array will
touch every location in memory from the location of the
first element to that of the last element.  The C-style
part means that the data is laid out such that the last index
is the fastest varying as one scans though the array's
memory.

constants.name: Fortran
constants.doc:
Fortran really means Fortran-style contiguious.  The
contiguous part means that there are no 'skipped
elements'.  That is, that a flat_iter over the array will
touch every location in memory from the location of the
first element to that of the last element.  The Fortran-style
part means that the data is laid out such that the first index
is the fastest varying as one scans though the array's
memory.

instance_methods.name: as_strided
instance_methods.doc:
as_strided creates a view into the array given the exact strides and
shape. This means it manipulates the internal data structure of
a Tensor and, if done incorrectly, the array elements can point
to invalid memory and can corrupt results or crash your program.
It is advisable to always use the original x.strides when
calculating new strides to avoid reliance on a contiguous
memory layout.

Furthermore, arrays created with this function often contain self
overlapping memory, so that two elements are identical.
Vectorized write operations on such arrays will typically be
unpredictable. They may even give different results for
small, large, or transposed arrays. Since writing to these
arrays has to be tested and done with great care, you may want
to use writeable=false to avoid accidental write operations.
instance_methods.summary: as_strided creates a view into the array given the exact strides and shape.

def.name: as_strided
def.body:
newflags = arr.flags.dup
newflags = newflags & ((~Num::ArrayFlags::Write) & (~Num::ArrayFlags::OwnData))
arr.class.new(arr.to_unsafe, shape, strides, newflags)

instance_methods.name: broadcast_to
instance_methods.doc:
Broadcasts an array to a new shape. A readonly view on the original array
with the given shape. It is typically not contiguous. Furthermore,
more than one element of a broadcasted array may refer to a single
memory location.
instance_methods.summary: Broadcasts an array to a new shape.

def.name: broadcast_to
def.body:
dim = newshape.size
defstrides = [0] * dim
sz = 1
dim.times do |i|
  defstrides[(dim - i) - 1] = sz
  sz = sz * newshape[(dim - i) - 1]
end
newstrides = broadcast_strides(newshape, arr.shape, defstrides, arr.strides)
newflags = arr.flags.dup
newflags = newflags & ((~Num::ArrayFlags::Write) & (~Num::ArrayFlags::OwnData))
arr.class.new(arr.to_unsafe, newshape, newstrides, newflags)

instance_methods.name: broadcastable
instance_methods.doc:
Determines if two shapes are broadcastable against each other.
The rules for checking this property are well defined:

Two dimensions are compatible if:
  - they are equal
  - one of them is equal to 1

If the axes of the array are different lengths, dimensions of
size one can be appended to one or the other in order to make
the arrays broadcastable against each other and satisfy the
rules for broadcastable dimensions.
instance_methods.summary: Determines if two shapes are broadcastable against each other.

def.name: broadcastable
def.body:
if arr.shape != other.shape
else
  return [] of Int32
end
sz = arr.shape.size
osz = other.shape.size
if sz == osz
  if broadcast_equal(arr.shape, other.shape)
    return broadcastable_shape(arr.shape, other.shape)
  end
else
  if sz > osz
    othershape = ([1] * (sz - osz)) + other.shape
    if broadcast_equal(arr.shape, othershape)
      return broadcastable_shape(arr.shape, othershape)
    end
  else
    selfshape = ([1] * (osz - sz)) + arr.shape
    if broadcast_equal(selfshape, other.shape)
      return broadcastable_shape(selfshape, other.shape)
    end
  end
end
raise(ShapeError.new("Shapes #{arr.shape} and #{other.shape} are not broadcastable"))

instance_methods.name: shape_to_strides
instance_methods.doc:
Takes in a shape, and a memory order type, and returns the
strides of an array matching the shape and layout.
Num.cr uses row major memory layout by default, and ClTensors
have this enforced, it is not possible to use col major storage
on a ClTensor.
instance_methods.summary: Takes in a shape, and a memory order type, and returns the strides of an array matching the shape and layout.
instance_methods.args_string: (shape : Array(Int32), layout : Num::OrderType = Num::RowMajor) : Array(Int32)

def.name: shape_to_strides
def.body:
accum = 1
ret = shape.clone
case layout
when Num::RowMajor
  (shape.size - 1).step(to: 0, by: -1) do |i|
    ret[i] = accum
    accum = accum * shape[i]
  end
else
  shape.size.times do |i|
    ret[i] = accum
    accum = accum * shape[i]
  end
end
ret

instance_methods.name: is_c_contiguous
instance_methods.doc: Checks that a tensor follows row major memory layout
instance_methods.summary: Checks that a tensor follows row major memory layout

def.name: is_c_contiguous
def.body:
if ndims != 0
else
  return true
end
if ndims == 1
  return (shape[0] == 1) || (strides[0] == 1)
end
sd = 1
(ndims - 1).step(to: 0, by: -1) do |i|
  dim = shape[i]
  if dim != 0
  else
    return true
  end
  if strides[i] == sd
  else
    return false
  end
  sd = sd * dim
end
true

def.body:

end

class_methods.name: linear_space
class_methods.args_string: (start : Number, stop : Number, num = 50, endpoint = true)

def.name: linear_space
def.body:
if num > 0
else
  raise(NumInternal::ValueError.new("Number of samples must be non-negative"))
end
div = endpoint ? num - 1 : num
start = start * 1.0
stop = stop * 1.0
y = Tensor.range(Float64.new(num))
delta = stop - start
if num > 1
  step = delta / div
  if step == 0
    raise(NumInternal::ValueError.new("Cannot have a step of 0"))
  end
  y = y * step
else
  y = y * delta
end
y = y + start
if endpoint && num > 1
  y[y.shape[0] - 1] = stop
end
y

def.name: vander
def.body:

  raise(NumInternal::ShapeError.new("Vandermonde matrices must\n        be initialized with a one-dimensional Tensor"))
end
n = n.nil? ? x.size : n.as(Int32)
Tensor(T).new(x.size, n) do |i, j|
  offset = increasing ? j : (n - j) - 1
  x[i].value ** offset
end

constructors.doc:
Yields an array from a provided number of rows and columns.
This can quickly create matrices, useful for several `Tensor` creattion
methods such as the underlying implementation of `eye`, and `diag`.

This method does provide *i* and *j* variables for the passed block,
so no offset calculations need to be done by the user.

def.name: new
def.body:
data = Pointer(T).malloc(nrows * ncols) do |idx|
  i = idx // ncols
  j = idx % ncols
  yield i, j
end
if (nrows == 0) || (ncols == 0)
  raise(NumInternal::ShapeError.new("Cannot initialize an empty matrix"))
end
strides = NumInternal.shape_to_strides([nrows, ncols], Num::RowMajor)
new(data, [nrows, ncols], strides)

instance_methods.name: cholesky
instance_methods.doc:
Cholesky decomposition.

Return the Cholesky decomposition, L * L.H, of the square matrix a, where
L is lower-triangular and .H is the conjugate transpose operator (which
is the ordinary transpose if a is real-valued). a must be Hermitian
(symmetric if real-valued) and positive-definite. Only L is actually
returned.

```crystal
t = Tensor.from_array([[2, -1, 0], [-1, 2, -1], [0, -1, 2]]).astype(Float32)
puts t.cholesky

# Tensor([[ 1.414,    0.0,    0.0],
#         [-0.707,  1.225,    0.0],
#         [   0.0, -0.816,  1.155]])
```
instance_methods.summary: Cholesky decomposition.

Return the Cholesky decomposition, L * L.H, of the square matrix a, where
L is lower-triangular and .H is the conjugate transpose operator (which
is the ordinary transpose if a is real-valued). a must be Hermitian
(symmetric if real-valued) and positive-definite. Only L is actually
returned.

```crystal
t = Tensor.from_array([[2, -1, 0], [-1, 2, -1], [0, -1, 2]]).astype(Float32)
puts t.cholesky

# Tensor([[ 1.414,    0.0,    0.0],
#         [-0.707,  1.225,    0.0],
#         [   0.0, -0.816,  1.155]])
```
instance_methods.summary: Cholesky decomposition.

def.body:
assert_square_matrix(self)
char = lower ? 'L' : 'U'
lapack(potrf, char.ord.to_u8, shape[0], to_unsafe, shape[0])
lower ? tril! : triu!

instance_methods.name: det
instance_methods.doc:
Compute the determinant of an array.

```crystal
t = Tensor.from_array([[1, 2], [3, 4]]).astype(Float32)
puts t.det # => -2.0
```
instance_methods.summary: Compute the determinant of an array.

def.name: det
def.body:
assert_square_matrix(self)
a = dup(Num::ColMajor)
m, n = a.shape
ipiv = Pointer(Int32).malloc(n)
lapack(getrf, m, n, a.to_unsafe, n, ipiv)
ldet = Num.prod(a.diag_view)
detp = 1
n.times do |j|
  if (j + 1) != ipiv[j]
    detp = -detp
  end
end
ldet * detp

instance_methods.name: hessenberg
instance_methods.doc:
Compute Hessenberg form of a matrix.

The Hessenberg decomposition is:

```
A = Q H Q^H
```

where Q is unitary/orthogonal and H has only zero elements below the first sub-diagonal.
instance_methods.summary: Compute Hessenberg form of a matrix.

def.name: hessenberg
def.body:
assert_square_matrix(self)
a = dup(Num::ColMajor)
if a.shape[0] < 2
  return a
end
n = a.shape[0]
s = of_real_type(n)
ilo = 0
ihi = 0
lapack(gebal, 'B'.ord.to_u8, n, a.to_unsafe, n, ilo, ihi, s.to_unsafe)
tau = Tensor(T).new([n])
lapack(gehrd, n, ilo, ihi, a.to_unsafe, n, tau.to_unsafe)
Num.triu(a, -1)

b_trans = other.flags.contiguous? ? LibCblas::CblasTranspose::CblasNoTrans : LibCblas::CblasTranspose::CblasTrans
blas(ge, mm, a_trans, b_trans, m, n, k, blas_const(1.0), a.to_unsafe, lda, b.to_unsafe, ldb, blas_const(0.0), dest.to_unsafe, dest.shape[1])

instance_methods.name: qr
instance_methods.doc:
Compute the qr factorization of a matrix.

Factor the matrix a as qr, where q is orthonormal and r is
upper-triangular.

```crystal
t = Tensor.from_array([[0, 1], [1, 1], [1, 1], [2, 1]]).astype(Float32)
q, r = t.qr
puts q
puts r

# Tensor([[   0.0,  0.866],
#         [-0.408,  0.289],
#         [-0.408,  0.289],
#         [-0.816, -0.289]])
# Tensor([[-2.449, -1.633],
#         [   0.0,  1.155],
#         [   0.0,    0.0],
#         [   0.0,    0.0]])
```
instance_methods.summary: Compute the qr factorization of a matrix.

def.name: qr
def.body:
assert_matrix(self)
m, n = shape
k = {m, n}.min
a = dup(Num::ColMajor)
tau = (qr_setup(a, m, n, k))[0]
r = Num.triu(a)
lapack(orgqr, m, n, k, a.to_unsafe, m, tau.to_unsafe)
{a, r}

instance_methods.name: solve
instance_methods.doc:
Solve a linear matrix equation, or system of linear scalar equations.

Computes the exact solution, x, of the well-determined, i.e., full rank,
linear matrix equation ax = b.

```crystal
a = Tensor.from_array([[3, 1], [1, 2]]).astype(Float32)
b = Tensor.from_array([9, 8]).astype(Float32)
puts a.solve(b)

# Tensor([ 2.0,  3.0])
```
instance_methods.summary: Solve a linear matrix equation, or system of linear scalar equations.

def.name: solve
def.body:
assert_square_matrix(self)
a = dup(Num::ColMajor)
x = x.dup(Num::ColMajor)
n = a.shape[0]
m = x.ndims > 1 ? x.shape[1] : x.shape[0]
ipiv = Pointer(Int32).malloc(n)
lapack(gesv, n, m, a.to_unsafe, n, ipiv, x.to_unsafe, m)
x

instance_methods.name: svd
instance_methods.doc:
Singular Value Decomposition.

When a is a 2D array, it is factorized as u @ np.diag(s) @ vh = (u * s) @ vh,
where u and vh are 2D unitary arrays and s is a 1D array of as singular
values.

```crystal
t = Tensor.from_array([[0, 1], [1, 1], [1, 1], [2, 1]]).astype(Float32)
a, b, c = t.svd
puts a
puts b
puts c

# Tensor([[-0.204,  0.842, -0.331,  0.375],
#         [-0.465,  0.185,   -0.2, -0.843],
#         [-0.465,  0.185,  0.861,  0.092],
#         [-0.726, -0.473, -0.331,  0.375]])
# Tensor([ 3.02, 0.936])
# Tensor([[-0.788, -0.615],
#         [-0.615,  0.788]])
```
instance_methods.summary: Singular Value Decomposition.

def.name: svd
def.body:
assert_matrix(self)
a = dup(Num::ColMajor)
m, n = a.shape
mn = {m, n}.min
mx = {m, n}.max
s = Tensor(T).new([mn])
u = Tensor(T).new([m, m])
vt = Tensor(T).new([n, n])
lapack(gesdd, 'A'.ord.to_u8, m, n, a.to_unsafe, m, s.to_unsafe, u.to_unsafe, m, vt.to_unsafe, n, worksize: [{((5 * mn) * mn) + (5 * mn), (((2 * mx) * mn) + ((2 * mn) * mn)) + mn}.max, 8 * mn])
{u.transpose, s, vt.transpose}

def.name: tril!
def.body:
if ndims == 2
  tril2d(self, k)
else
  matrix_iter.each do |subm|
    tril2d(subm, k)
  end
end

def.name: triu!
def.body:
if ndims == 2
  triu2d(self, k)
else
  matrix_iter.each do |subm|
    triu2d(subm, k)
  end
end

def.name: blas
lapack
lapack_util
